newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan shares drop to lowest level since January.
newsitem.headline: Jordan shares drop to lowest level since January.

text.p: Jordan's shares drifted lower again on Tuesday to their lowest level since January, with trade battered by absence of outside buying along with a liquidity crunch, dealers said.
The official Amman Financial Market (AFM) index fell 0.10 percent to 151.63 points, close to levels at the beginning of January when the 60-share index started 1997 at 151.61 points.
Bloc purchases in heavyweight Arab Bank accounted for nearly half of Tuesday's turnover of 635,757 dinars ($898,000).
"The market was weak across the board," broker Husam al-Hanbali said.

Brokers attribute a bearish sentiment to a combination of factors including lack of outside institutional buying, a tight liquidity problem worsened by political uncertainty over the fate of Middle East peace.
Overall 20 shares fell, led by Arab Bank, which lost 1.5 dinars to 250 dinars in trade worth 312,010 dinars. Only 10 stock gained and 15 remained unchanged.

Brokers said the bank, which announced on Friday a 17.7 percent rise in 1996 net profits but declined to set a date for a planned bonus share offer, fell victim to the overall negative sentiment on the bourse.
The private Pearl Index of the 45 most-traded shares on the exchange shed 0.12 percent to 79.49 points, 4.68 percent down from the start of the year.
